channel.title: Help me out with this math problem
channel.description:
I don't get this one:
The profit margin is 2%. You are able to reduce your costs by 5. So your profit raises with 5. Let's get back to the start. Your net sales are X. How much does X have to increase, in order to raise your profit by 5? Keep the 2% profit margin in mind.
Thanks in advance!

item.title: Help me out with this math problem
item.dc:creator: @Eh_Pretty_Easy Eh Pretty Easy
item.description:
@Eh_Pretty_Easy wrote:

It would have to increase five times. If it’s 500 now, it would have to be 2500.

5000,02 = 10
25000,02 = 50

Read full topic
item.source: Help me out with this math problem

item.title: Help me out with this math problem
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Tenacious T:

[quote]The profit margin is 2%. You are able to reduce your costs by 5. So your profit raises with 5. Let’s get back to the start. Your net sales are X. How much does X have to increase, in order to raise your profit by 5? Keep the 2% profit margin in mind.

The 2% margin is actually non important in this question, also, the Net sales would not have to increase because it says you can even take away 5, and your profit raises by 5. So if anything you could reduce and still come up to 5.[/quote]

No.

I might have written down the question in an unclear way. The question is: how much do you have to raise your net sales to increase your profit with 5.

Read full topic
item.source: Help me out with this math problem

item.title: Help me out with this math problem
item.dc:creator: @Tenacious_T Tenacious T
item.description:
@Tenacious_T wrote:

The profit margin is 2%. You are able to reduce your costs by 5. So your profit raises with 5. Let's get back to the start. Your net sales are X. How much does X have to increase, in order to raise your profit by 5? Keep the 2% profit margin in mind.

The 2% margin is actually non important in this question, also, the Net sales would not have to increase because it says you can even take away 5, and your profit raises by 5. So if anything you could reduce and still come up to 5.

Read full topic
item.source: Help me out with this math problem

item.title: Help me out with this math problem
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

chrisn2323:

so the new profit should be 7% of the revenue?

No. The profit margin stays 2%. Lets say there are two moments. At moment 1 the net sales are X. At moment 2 the net sales are X+Y. The profit at moment 2 has increased with 5, compared to moment 1. So what is Y? How much have the net sales increased at moment 2, so that the profit is increased with 5?

So it can’t be 7, because you guys just take the 2% margin and add the rise of the profit to it. But that 2% stays 2%.

Read full topic
item.source: Help me out with this math problem
